title: Riot needs to remove chat from this game. It's causing teen suicides.

embed.description: We all love League of Legends but would you die for it? Unfortunately some people have whether they wanted to or not. Remember to stay safe out there and protect yourself on the rift and outside the rift. You may feed in game but no need to feed irl.

body:
This community is so toxic, and the report system is so fucked, you'll often get 4 people reporting a new player because they fed and because that one player tries to defend themselves vs a torrent of abuse and because 4 ppl report them for it they get banned and the toxic people who ruin this game for everyone (and were likely the cause of their team losing) get off scott free, because theyve played for years and they only say small bits and know how to work the system and have high honor. 

The honor system, reports system everything should just go. chat should be deleted fullstop and failing that, have a chat filter installed that only allows you to say things pertinent to the game. there is no reason for riot to keep allowing this other than because they think it will make them more money because they know that young kids who dont know how harmful their words can be wont play if they cant abuse others.

Why am I so passionate about this? I have a younger brother who also plays the game. Today one of his friends committed suicide, and it came to light that 3 of his **13 YEAR OLD** friends frequently self harm as a result of the abuse they receive during games. whether the game brings out feelings they have suppressed or whether it is just so toxic it does this alone, Riot have a duty to address this issue and quite frankly so far their attempts are half arsed. Even their customer support is ridden with bad attitude and passive aggressive mentality. 

Toxicity is ruining this game and children's lives. Riot need to grow a fucking pair of balls and fix this issue instead of distracting everyone with new champs and rebranding.

I'm sorry but if you can't be sensitive to this issue then you're part of the problem.

Imagine if businesses employed that strategy. "Well, we're receiving complaints about one cashier making rude remarks about customers on their way out, so let's just fire everyone who works the registers and set up self-checkout lanes to replace them". It's asinine, and causes more harm than good. Nobody in their right mind would try to solve problems that way.

> ...however the ban system is deeply flawed and riot has done very little to resolve it.

The issue you brought up with the punishment system is an issue of the players themselves, not the system. If people start flaming/counterflaming under pressure instead of muting irritants and instigators, then the punishment is on them. They had the option to follow the rules, and unless it's some obvious case of a gullible person getting tricked into saying something zero-tolerance, then it's largely going to be on each player to not flame.

> I mean the least I'm asking for is for phrases like " kill yourself, fuck, shit, %%%%, noob, inter etc." to be censored, if riot actually doesnt want toxicity, why would they not censor these words?

The simplest answer is, even for the more egregious offenses (hate speech, encouragements of self-harm), there's so many ways a person can work around a censoring filter that it'd be pointless and a waste of effort to try and proactively censor every variation of the word.

As for swearing (fuck, shit, etc.), the Mature Language Filter (which is turned on by default, IIRC) already handles those, and insults (whether direct and intentioned like "inter" or context-sensitive like "noob") are much in the same boat as the former case. Too many variations to censor entirely.

> why wait for someone to report someone and then allow a system to go yeah he said one of those words but he has lvl 5 honor so its chill, when you could just stop those words from being said.

This statement, particularly the inclusion of Honor Level 5, is telling of a lack of information/misinformation on the punishment system.

It legitimately doesn't matter what Honor Level you are. You could be Honor Level 5, and the IFS will still punish you. It makes no difference to the system if you're Honor Level 0 or just on the verge of Honor 5 - breaking the rules will incur a punishment.

As for "just stopping the words from being said" - and, to a similar degree, the argument against a reactive punishment system - Riot has another reason to use Reports instead of just trying to filter everything out before it can get said. And that is that Riot believes that every player should have a say in what they find acceptable in a given match, and that belief is exemplified in the application of the Report feature.

Do you have a group of friends and play in a premade and tell off-color jokes? Well, your decision to not report those friends is your way of saying "I'm okay with this type of humor.". Likewise, if one such joke gets used in the company of a random player, that random player can report it, and in so doing, tell Riot "I'm not okay with this."

Riot would rather reactively punish behavior that players deemed worth reporting than try to go out of their way to preemptively police their game and make sure everything - even the external factors that they really can't control, IE, the players - is going according to their script.

> Riot have done sweet FA about this issue and there are so many simple fixes.

Riot has done sweet fuckall _that you've seen._ A tree falls in the forest, etc., etc.

And "simple" does not mean "good", and it doesn't mean "right". It just means "simple".

> If they can't be bothered to spend the time, just cut it all together.

This _is_ a simple solution, but it's neither a good solution nor the right solution. And again, it's ignorant of the fact that Riot is already actively working against the problem that the simple solution overshoots.

> Pings are more than enough to communicate in the game...

This isn't true. I can't ask people to ward a specific area through pings. I can't tell people that I plan to push out bottom lane for pressure before heading to Baron through pings. I can't tell people that my lane opponent is starting to get fed through pings.

Those are just three things I could think of right off-hand, but there's still a lot of stuff that pings don't cover. They're a tool, not a say-all, end-all, be-all.

> ...if you wanna chat to someone add them after and communicate using 3rd party programs?

And what if my only interest in chatting with them is in the match that I play with them? What if I want to commend my opponent for a good play, but would have easily forgotten it by the end of the match? What if I don't want to build up a pile of friends I don't actively talk to or give them an avenue to talk to me outside of League?

I've said it once, and I'll say it again: _"Simple" does not mean "good"._ Your simple solution causes too much hassle and harm for it to be remotely viable, and, again; it completely overshoots the problem in hopes of trying to sweep it up with everything else.

You need to think about the ramifications and after-effects of your proposal. Sure, the natural response to the change might be intuitive for _you_, but there are millions upon millions of players out there who definitely would not do things the way you would. And I know for a fact that I'm one such player.
